Critics say boosters conflating different types of AI.

ai, artificial intelligence, openai, sam altman, anthropic, chatgpt, dario amodei, eric schmidt, climate change, emissionsRead

<script>/*<![CDATA[*/ __tnt.recentFive = {
    /*
     * Gets the data stored in 'tnt:recent:five'
     * Returns Array
     */
        get:function(){
            if(window.localStorage && localStorage.getItem('tnt:recent:five')!=null){
                try{ return JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('tnt:recent:five')); } catch {}
            }

            return [];
        },

    /*
     * Sets the 'tnt:recent:five' localStorage item
     * Returns boolean
     */
        set:function(data){
            if(window.localStorage){
                try{ 
                    localStorage.setItem('tnt:recent:five', JSON.stringify(data));
                    return true;
                } catch {}
            }

            return false;
        },

    /*
     * Adds the most recent item, prunes any duplicates, and trims the array down to 5 items
     * Returns Array on success, false on fail 
     */
        add:function(asset){
            var assets = __tnt.recentFive.get();
            assets.unshift(asset);

            if(assets.length > 1){
                assets = assets.filter(function(item, index, a){ return a.indexOf(item) == index });

                while(assets.length>5){
                    assets.pop();
                }
            }

            if(__tnt.recentFive.set(assets)){ return assets; }
            return false;
        }
    }; /*]]>*/</script>

                            <div id="tncms-region-article_body_top" class="tncms-region hidden-print"></div>

                            <div id="article-body"  itemprop="articleBody" class="asset-content  subscriber-premium"false>
                                <meta itemprop="isAccessibleForFree" content="false"/>
                                
                                
                                <div class="subscriber-preview"><p>To hear some of the biggest boosters of artificial intelligence tell it, we shouldnt dwell on how the technologys development is producing large and growing greenhouse-gas emissions because AI itself will help us solve the climate-change crisis.</p></div><div class="subscriber-preview"><p>OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei and former Google CEO Eric Schmidt have all articulated some version of this argument. But critics contend such assertions are misguided, noting that the kind of AI thats largely driving the increase in emissions is not the same type that should be expected to address climate change.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Despite assertions by people like Schmidt and Altman, its not at all obvious that generative AI technologies such the large language model that underlies ChatGPT are going to help solve climate change, said Alex de Vries, founder of Digiconomist, an online publication that focuses on technologys environmental impact.</p></div><div id="tncms-region-article_instory_top" class="tncms-region hidden-print"><div id="tncms-block-2743590" class="tncms-block"><section id="block-2743590" class="block emphasis-h3   " ></section></div><div id="tncms-block-2535613" class="tncms-block"><div class="tnt-ads-container text-center  hidden"  data-dmp-hide-segment='["our_partners"]'>
        <div id="ad-2535613" class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-lazy="true" data-refresh="true" >
            <script>
                googletag.cmd.push(function() {
                    __tnt.ads.dfp.adDisplay = function(callback) {
                        if (typeof callback === "function") {
                            var adSettings = {
                                'audience': 'our_partners',
                                'block': true
                            };
                            if (callback(adSettings)) {
                                document.getElementById("ad-2535613").style.display = 'none';
                                return false;
                            }
                        }
                        googletag.display('ad-2535613');
                        
                    }
                    __tnt.ads.dfp.adDisplay(__tnt.ads.dfp.dmp.audienceCheck);
                    
                });
            </script>
        </div>
    </div>
</div></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>I definitely wouldn't count on these models to solve the problems of the world at the moment, de Vries said.</p></div><div class="inline-asset inline-image layout-horizontal  subscriber-hide  tnt-inline-asset tnt-inline-relcontent tnt-inline-image tnt-inline-relation-child tnt-inline-presentation-default tnt-inline-alignment-left tnt-inline-width-half"><figure class="photo layout-horizontal hover-expand letterbox-style-blur"><span class="expand hidden-print"

                <div class="tnt-blurred-image">
             <img src="https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/0/68/06854756-4f39-4eb2-8497-7ff4292adda6/683113004b0c9.image.jpg?resize=200%2C133" alt="" aria-hidden="true" loading="lazy" height="133" width="200"/>
         </div>

                    <figcaption class="caption">
                            
                                <span class="caption-text">
                                    <p>Elon Musk talks with former Google CEO Eric Schmidt before President Donald Trump speaks at the Future Investment Initiative (FII) Institute summit in Miami Beach, Fla., Wednesday, Feb. 19, 2025.</p>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                            
                                <span class="credit">
                                    <span itemprop="author" class="tnt-byline">Pool via Associated Press</span>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                        <span class="clearfix"></span>
                    </figcaption>
                
            
        </figure></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>But thats precisely what people such as Altman, Amodei and Schmidt are arguing generative AI will do. At an AI event in Washington, D.C., in October, Schmidt <a href="https://mashable.com/article/former-google-ceo-invest-ai-despite-climate-concerns" target="_blank">made the case most explicitly</a>.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>We're not going to hit the climate goals anyway because we're not organized to do it, Schmidt said at the event. I'd rather bet on AI solving the problem than constraining [its development] and having the problem [anyway].</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>In a blog post last fall entitled The Intelligence Age, Altman contended that developers are only a few thousand days away from <a href="https://ia.samaltman.com/" target="_blank">creating an AI superintelligence that will transform society</a> for the better. Among the many benefits this advanced AI will provide will be fixing the climate, he said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Similarly, in his own blog post around the same time, entitled Machines of Loving Grace: How AI Could Transform the World for the Better, Amodei argued that the advent of what he called powerful AI will be a boon to humanity in a wide range of areas, including helping to mitigate climate change.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Although he acknowledged that this powerful AI could come out of a different technology, Amodei argued it will likely develop out of large language models, the generative AI technology that powers chatbots such as ChatGPT and Anthropics own Claude.</p></div><div class="inline-asset inline-image layout-horizontal  subscriber-hide  tnt-inline-asset tnt-inline-relcontent tnt-inline-image tnt-inline-relation-child tnt-inline-presentation-default tnt-inline-alignment-right tnt-inline-width-half"><figure class="photo layout-horizontal hover-expand letterbox-style-blur"><span class="expand hidden-print"

https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/4/dc/4dc95d31-493c-419f-94ba-e76fa94a7bbc/683113a78aa47.image.jpg?resize=990%2C660 990w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/4/dc/4dc95d31-493c-419f-94ba-e76fa94a7bbc/683113a78aa47.image.jpg?resize=1333%2C888 1333w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/4/dc/4dc95d31-493c-419f-94ba-e76fa94a7bbc/683113a78aa47.image.jpg 2008w" />
            </div>
                
                <div class="tnt-blurred-image">
             <img src="https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/4/dc/4dc95d31-493c-419f-94ba-e76fa94a7bbc/683113a78aa47.image.jpg?resize=200%2C133" alt="" aria-hidden="true" loading="lazy" height="133" width="200"/>
         </div>
            </div>
            
                
                
                    <figcaption class="caption">
                            
                                <span class="caption-text">
                                    <p>Dario Amodei, co-founder and chief executive of Anthropic, at an undisclosed location, June 10, 2023.</p>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                            
                                <span class="credit">
                                    <span itemprop="author" class="tnt-byline">Massimo Berruti  2025 The New York Times Company </span>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                        <span class="clearfix"></span>
                    </figcaption>
                
            
        </figure></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>That AI can be expected to help develop new clean-energy technologies. systems for removing carbon from the atmosphere and more climate-friendly lab-grown meat, Amodei said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Theres good reason to think that AI-enhanced research will give us the means to make mitigating climate change far less costly and disruptive, he said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>AI critics have <a href="https://www.technologyreview.com/2024/09/28/1104588/sorry-ai-wont-fix-climate-change/" target="_blank">raised numerous objections to these lines of argument</a>. They say its advocates are willing to accept certain harm now  increasing temperatures, rising sea levels, drought, flooding and more factors are considered consequences of climate change, according to the scientific consensus  in favor of future benefits that are speculative at best.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Whats more, reducing emissions and mitigating climate change dont necessarily require new technological solutions, according to AI skeptics. Current and already widely available technologies such as solar panels, electric vehicles and heat pumps could dramatically reduce dependence on fossil fuels. There just needs to be the political and societal will to swap out older, more climate-harming technologies for them.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Claims of AIs future potential for helping address climate change come as emissions related to AI are rapidly rising  and on track to continue to do so.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Large language models and other generative AI technologies require vast amounts of data and computing power to train. Developers such as OpenAI and Anthropic have bet that their systems will get ever better with more and more training data. But increased data leads to a rise in computing power needed to process it, which requires more energy use and is <a href="https://www.sfexaminer.com/news/technology/chatgpt-other-ai-tools-come-with-significant-climate-costs/article_ed96060a-0359-11ef-ae12-3b49734e50c5.html" target="_blank">increasingly leading to more greenhouse emissions</a>.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>And thats just in training the models. Running the models  such as when ChatGPT responds to a query  has an ongoing energy cost that also leads to more emissions.</p></div><div class="inline-asset inline-image layout-horizontal  subscriber-hide  tnt-inline-asset tnt-inline-relcontent tnt-inline-image tnt-inline-relation-child tnt-inline-presentation-default tnt-inline-width-full"><figure class="photo layout-horizontal hover-expand letterbox-style-blur"><span class="expand hidden-print"

                <div class="tnt-blurred-image">
             <img src="https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/59/a596c7bf-5807-4b14-8bff-b217b9d4928a/683114687d294.image.jpg?resize=200%2C112" alt="" aria-hidden="true" loading="lazy" height="112" width="200"/>

                    <figcaption class="caption">
                            
                                <span class="caption-text">
                                    <p>Data centers  such as the Amazon Web Services facility in Boardman, Ore.  create more work for electricians in the nearby area.</p>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                            
                                <span class="credit">
                                    <span itemprop="author" class="tnt-byline">Jenny Kane/Associated Press, File</span>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                        <span class="clearfix"></span>
                    </figcaption>
                
            
        </figure></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>The power needs for models from OpenAI, Anthropic, Meta, Apple and other tech giants has been reflected in the rapidly growing percentage of energy going to the data centers that run them. Data centers <a href="https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/private-capital/our-insights/how-data-centers-and-the-energy-sector-can-sate-ais-hunger-for-power" target="_blank">accounted for 3.7% of U.S. energy use in 2023</a>, according to a report last year from McKinsey. The consulting firm expected that portion to grow to 4.3% last year, 5.2% this year and 11.7% in 2030.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Worldwide data-center energy use <a href="https://iea.blob.core.windows.net/assets/34eac603-ecf1-464f-b813-2ecceb8f81c2/EnergyandAI.pdf" target="_blank">has grown by 12% a year since 2017</a>, and it accounted for 1.5% of total energy consumption last year, according to a report last month from the International Energy Agency. The agency predicted their energy consumption will more than double by 2030 and account for 3% of worldwide demand.</p></div><div id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle" class="tncms-region hidden-print"><div id="tncms-block-2960908" class="tncms-block boxed-title findings-title"><span data-asset="3af9df0f-0cb6-41d0-93bd-417c5ead8c99"></span><section id="block-2960908" class="block emphasis-h3   " ><div class="clearfix">

             <a href="/news/politics/trump-floats-sf-action-after-da-rejects-calls-for-troops/article_33af8b14-55c3-416a-97aa-de9e2fa6cef3.html#tncms-source=top-stories-article" class="tnt-asset-link" aria-label="DA Brooke Jenkins rejects call for National Guard in SF">

        <div class="clearfix hidden-xs"></div>
        
        
        </div>
        </div></section></div><div id="tncms-block-3468042" class="tncms-block"><section id="block-3468042" class="block emphasis-h3   " ><div id="html-asset-3468042">
            <div class="html-content">
<div data-stn-player="0Y4IOBUG"></div>
<script async type="text/javascript" src="https://embed.sendtonews.com/player3/embedcode.js?fk=0Y4IOBUG"></script>
</div>
        </div></section></div></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Altman and others in the AI sector have promoted the idea that nuclear power will help meet that growing energy demand and reduce the technologys climate impact, but <a href="https://www.sfexaminer.com/news/technology/ai-is-boosting-interest-in-nuclear-power-but-won-t-soon-benefit-from-it/article_4237704a-b287-11ef-ac85-b740331d93fa.html" target="_blank">new nuclear plants are unlikely to come online anytime soon</a>, power experts have said. Instead, to meet the rapidly growing power demands of generative AI, utilities are delaying the planned decommissioning of older coal plants and making plans to build new natural-gas plants.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>As a result, big AI players including Microsoft, Google and Salesforce have warned that their emissions are increasing or <a href="https://www.sfexaminer.com/news/technology/salesforce-quietly-drops-key-climate-goals-to-cut-emissions/article_29bb6e4d-72f0-452f-b5b6-1ae19f41e985.html" target="_blank">backed off of their emissions-reduction targets</a>.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Some forms of artificial intelligence are already playing a role in the fight against climate change.</p></div><div class="inline-asset inline-image layout-horizontal  subscriber-hide  tnt-inline-asset tnt-inline-relcontent tnt-inline-image tnt-inline-relation-child tnt-inline-presentation-default tnt-inline-alignment-left tnt-inline-width-half"><figure class="photo layout-horizontal hover-expand letterbox-style-blur"><span class="expand hidden-print"

                   data-photo-target=".photo-5951cef4-011c-11f0-a674-873f003c4b79"

                   data-target="#photo-carousel-3af9df0f-0cb6-41d0-93bd-417c5ead8c99">

https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/95/5951cef4-011c-11f0-a674-873f003c4b79/67d4a1c64e2e5.image.jpg?resize=1333%2C1163 1333w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/95/5951cef4-011c-11f0-a674-873f003c4b79/67d4a1c64e2e5.image.jpg?resize=1476%2C1288 1476w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/95/5951cef4-011c-11f0-a674-873f003c4b79/67d4a1c64e2e5.image.jpg 2008w" />
            </div>
                
                <div class="tnt-blurred-image">
             <img src="https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/95/5951cef4-011c-11f0-a674-873f003c4b79/67d4a1c64e2e5.image.jpg?resize=200%2C175" alt="" aria-hidden="true" loading="lazy" height="175" width="200"/>
         </div>
            </div>
            
                
                
                    <figcaption class="caption">
                            
                                <span class="caption-text">
                                    <p>Jathan Sadowski, senior lecturer, Department of Human Centred Computing, Monash University in Melbourne, Australia.</p>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                            
                                <span class="credit">
                                    <span itemprop="author" class="tnt-byline">Victor Tikhanov - Ender Kinograp</span>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                        <span class="clearfix"></span>
                    </figcaption>
                
            
        </figure></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Scientists have long been using machine learning to model the climate and make predictions about climate-change effects, said Jathan Sadowski, a senior lecturer in the Emerging Technologies Research Lab at Monash Universitys Department of Human Centred Computing in Melbourne, Australia. Similarly, electrical-grid operators use machine-learning models to optimize and manage the distribution of energy, he said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>But those forms of artificial intelligence are distinct from the large language models that power generative AI systems such as ChatGPT, Sadowski said. And, he and other critical experts say, they tend to be much more energy efficient.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>When it comes to talking about how AI could help fight climate change, theres a real conflation by people really invested in ... the generative AI form of machine learning, he said. Theyre conflating what theyre invested in and what their business is with these other forms of machine learning.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Similarly, types of artificial intelligence are already being used and could be used in the future in the field of materials science to analyze and try to identify substances that might be useful in making better batteries for energy energy storage or more efficient solar cells, he said. But the kinds of models that are useful in those cases are typically ones that are specifically designed for such tasks with data particular to specific areas of knowledge, he and other AI experts said.</p></div><div class="inline-asset inline-image layout-vertical  subscriber-hide  tnt-inline-asset tnt-inline-relcontent tnt-inline-image tnt-inline-relation-child tnt-inline-presentation-default tnt-inline-alignment-right tnt-inline-width-half"><figure class="photo layout-vertical hover-expand letterbox-style-blur"><span class="expand hidden-print"

https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=300%2C425 300w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=400%2C567 400w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=540%2C765 540w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=640%2C907 640w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=750%2C1063 750w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=990%2C1403 990w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=1035%2C1466 1035w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=1200%2C1700 1200w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg 1333w" />
            </div>
                
                <div class="tnt-blurred-image">
             <img src="https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/25/f25d2511-72f8-49e4-95fc-e1c35d93d6a3/68311561c9f81.image.jpg?resize=200%2C283" alt="" aria-hidden="true" loading="lazy" height="283" width="200"/>
         </div>
            </div>
            
                
                
                    <figcaption class="caption">
                            
                                <span class="caption-text">
                                    <p>The ChatGPT app, in Brooklyn, Dec. 7, 2022.</p>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                            
                                <span class="credit">
                                    <span itemprop="author" class="tnt-byline">Jackie Molloy  2022 The New York Times Company</span>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                        <span class="clearfix"></span>
                    </figcaption>
                
            
        </figure></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Generative AI technologies such as ChatGPT and video generators such as OpenAIs Sora might have some societal value, said Gary Marcus, a professor emeritus at New York University and the author of Taming Silicon Valley: How We Can Ensure That AI Works for Us. But they come with whats likely a serious climate cost, he said, and theyre <a href="https://www.sfexaminer.com/news/technology/why-researchers-argue-that-chatgpt-output-is-a-bunch-of-bs/article_85f990c0-4896-11ef-8ec5-b73150b9b33e.html" target="_blank">prone to errors</a>.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Thats not the kind of system thats going to help with the climate, Marcus said. Chatbots are not reliable enough even to follow the rules of chess, let alone make some stunning new advance in material science or something like that.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Altman wasnt available for comment, and OpenAI representative Jason Deutrom declined to comment beyond Altmans blog post. But he pointed to an announcement the company made in January that it had <a href="https://openai.com/index/strengthening-americas-ai-leadership-with-the-us-national-laboratories/" target="_blank">signed an agreement with the U.S. National Laboratories</a> to provide them with so-called reasoning models, which attempt to answer complex queries by breaking them down into separate parts, to help with such efforts as improving cybersecurity, finding treatments for diseases and basic science.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Representatives for Anthropic and Schmidt did not respond to requests for comment.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Much of the assertion that Altman and Schmidt make about generative AI helping with climate change is built on the notion that the technology underlying ChatGPT will soon get so smart  because of all the data its taking in  that it will surpass human intelligence and will be able to come up with ideas that humans couldnt.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>But such advocates dont ever really explain how a technology thats not sentient and doesnt have any real notion of the actual physical world will somehow evolve into what they like to call artificial general intelligence, said Emily Bender and Alex Hanna, <a href="https://www.sfexaminer.com/news/technology/the-ai-con-book-aims-to-pierce-artificial-intelligence-hype/article_dae92bab-6e68-4ba8-9b52-76b640f1d48d.html" target="_blank">co-authors of the new book</a> The AI Con: How to Fight Big Techs Hype and Create the Future We Want.</p></div><div class="inline-asset inline-image layout-horizontal  subscriber-hide  tnt-inline-asset tnt-inline-relcontent tnt-inline-image tnt-inline-relation-child tnt-inline-presentation-default tnt-inline-alignment-left tnt-inline-width-half"><figure class="photo layout-horizontal hover-expand letterbox-style-blur"><span class="expand hidden-print"

                   data-photo-target=".photo-34e24b95-bfa8-452e-91a9-80b734f22f28"

                   data-target="#photo-carousel-3af9df0f-0cb6-41d0-93bd-417c5ead8c99">
                <span class="fas tnt-expand"></span>
            </span>

                    data-toggle="modal"

https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/4e/34e24b95-bfa8-452e-91a9-80b734f22f28/681a77a362c73.image.jpg?resize=1333%2C887 1333w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/4e/34e24b95-bfa8-452e-91a9-80b734f22f28/681a77a362c73.image.jpg?resize=1476%2C982 1476w, https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/4e/34e24b95-bfa8-452e-91a9-80b734f22f28/681a77a362c73.image.jpg 2008w" />
            </div>
                
                <div class="tnt-blurred-image">
             <img src="https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sfexaminer.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/4e/34e24b95-bfa8-452e-91a9-80b734f22f28/681a77a362c73.image.jpg?resize=200%2C133" alt="" aria-hidden="true" loading="lazy" height="133" width="200"/>
         </div>
            </div>
            
                
                
                    <figcaption class="caption">
                            
                                <span class="caption-text">
                                    <p>University of Washington linguistics professor Emily Bender, who is a faculty member in its computer-science school, co-authored The AI Con.</p>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                            
                                <span class="credit">
                                    <span itemprop="author" class="tnt-byline">Courtesy Susan Doupe Photography</span>
                                </span>
                            
                        
                        <span class="clearfix"></span>
                    </figcaption>
                
            
        </figure></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>ChatGPT and similar LLM-based chatbots are designed to produce text that looks like it could have been written by a human, said Bender, a linguistics professor at the University of Washington whos also on the faculty of that institutions information and computer science and engineering schools. Based on the data they were trained on, they essentially predict what word would come next in a sentence.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Whatever sense users might have that ChatGPT is actually intelligent comes from the users themselves ascribing meaning to its output, Bender said. If you take away users meaning-making, its clear that its basically the same thing as a Magic 8 Ball, she said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p>Are we going to have a Magic 8 Ball solving climate change for us? she said. I dont think so.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p><em>A previous version of this article incorrectly listed one of the University of Washington schools on which Emily Bender is a faculty member. In fact, she is a faculty member of its computer science and engineering school.</em></p></div><div class="subscriber-only" style="display:none"><p class="p1"><em>If you have a tip about tech, startups or the venture industry, contact Troy Wolverton at </em><em><a href="mailto:twolverton@sfexaminer.com">twolverton@sfexaminer.com</a> or via text or Signal at 415.515.5594.</em></p></div><div id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom" class="tncms-region hidden-print"></div>
                                <div id="tncms-region-article_bottom_content" class="tncms-region hidden-print"></div>
                                
                            </div>

readabilityObject.title: Why ChatGPT is unlikely to solve climate change
readabilityObject.excerpt: Critics say boosters conflating different types of AI.

finalizedMeta.title: Why ChatGPT is unlikely to solve climate change
finalizedMeta.description: Critics say boosters conflating different types of AI.
finalizedMeta.creator: Troy Wolverton | Examiner staff writer
finalizedMeta.subject: ai

metadata.author: Troy Wolverton | Examiner staff writer
metadata.title: Why ChatGPT, generative AI unlikely to solve climate change | Technology | sfexaminer.com
metadata.description: Generative AI boosters like Sam Altman say we shouldnt worry the technology is boosting emissions, because it will help fix climate change. Critics say Altman and others are confusing the issue.
metadata.firstParagraph: Sam Altman, OpenAIs chief executive and co-founder of World, during the startups launch in San Francisco, April 30, 2025. OpenAI said it was buying io, a start-up founded by Jony Ive, the designer of the iPhone, to usher in a new era of artificial intelligence hardware.
